top_comment.text:
I'm a big fan of John Krasinski so by default, I follow Emily as well. I 
have finally figured out what bothers me about Emily. She is not feminine. 
Beauty and femininity are not the same. I watch a lot of her interviews and 
her actions. Who says about their baby that they are "Stinking Cute". 
Please don't tell me that is the way they describe cuteness in England. I 
feel she has a lot of Tom Boy in her. She also says she doesn't cry easily. 
I'm not sexist but that, IMO, also is something woman, who are generally 
more sensitive, do. Listen, I'm a fan of hers so this is not a bashing of 
Emily by any means. Just an observation.﻿

comments.text:

comments.author: haitianxu

comments.text:
+Anne Ramsay <--personal insults: 3, valid point: 0

All evidence point towards you being a troll, but I'll be the bigger person 
here and give you one more chance to provide a valid argument that 
addresses the point that I've repeatedly made, the point that you've 
repeatedly avoided in favor of personal insults.

If you have no argument, go away, stop responding. Keep trolling, and your 
post will be deleted and you banned from my thread. I'm here for an 
intellectual discussion, not waste time on trolls and juvenile personal 
insults. This is your final warning.
comments.author: haitianxu

comments.text:
I think you need to get some professional help, you are so angry over 
something so small.
comments.author: Anne Ramsay

comments.text:
+Anne Ramsay <--and still resorting to personal insults (and not even 
clever ones. Get a job? Really?), and still no argument against my actual 
point.

What's wrong with urination? Why do you find it gross? Can you explain 
that? Do you get grossed out when you pee? Which part of peeing is 
non-natural?

Breastfeeding, urination and defecation are but different, natural ways we 
expel bodily fluids, they all serve natural biological purposes, can you 
explain why you find 2 of them arbitrarily gross, and one of them not?

Oh, pooping is gross because...it involves "bowel movement"? That's your 
argument? Really? How about breastfeeding is gross because "it involves the 
engorgement of the mammary gland"?

Do you even know what you are talking about?
comments.author: haitianxu

comments.text:
I really think you need to find a hobby or a job, the topic of breast 
feeding came up due to the fact she is a new mother, nothing in the 
conversation had anything to do with urination (not peeing) or bowel 
movements (not pooping).  It was a natural progression in the conversation, 
so your comments about "basic logic" are so silly, all you are doing is 
making your self look stupid.

BASIC LOGIC!
comments.author: Anne Ramsay

comments.text:
+Anne Ramsay It seems that none of you can actually provide a valid 
argument against my point.

If you think breastfeeding isn't an inappropriate topic on a daytime talk 
show because "a lot of mom watch the show" and "all moms breastfeed", then 
basic logic indicates you have even less problem with the topics of peeing 
and pooping on daytime TV shows because "shows are watched by humans" and 
"all humans pee and poop".

Basic logic. Or is it too hard for you?
comments.author: haitianxu

comments.text: It seams you are the only one missing that basic skill.
comments.author: Anne Ramsay

comments.text:
+Anne Ramsay News flash: 100% of the population pee and poop, those are 
completely normal human activities, therefore it's okay to have peeing and 
pooping on any daytime TV show by your logic, right?

Learn to use basic logic.
comments.author: haitianxu

comments.text:
Since the majority of people who watch this are Moms...totally normal...now 
if this was on Sponge Bob I would agree...grow up!
comments.author: Anne Ramsay

comments.text:
+Mr Mustard Of course they're not gross or unacceptable for someone who 
don't mind seeing peeping, pooping and sex on daytime television simply 
because they're "natural acts". That would satisfy your perversion and 
that's probably just the way you want it. You are a libertine after all - 
an angry, name-calling libertine at that. Are you forgetting your own 
arguments, or do you need me to quote them for you?
comments.author: haitianxu

comments.text:
+haitianxu All you're doing is noisily complaining about two women 
discussing babies and breastfeeding. It's not 'gross' and it's not 
'unacceptable' for daytime TV as kids learn this stuff when they're very 
young. Like I said, it's only you getting angry over nothing at all.
comments.author: Mean Mr Mustard

comments.text:
+Mr Mustard And yet you have no argument against it, except repetitive name 
calling and personal insults. And why is that?

The only ridiculous argument here is yours, thinking something is kosher 
for daytime TV simply because it's "a natural part of being human". Let's 
put breastfeeding on Ellen and while we're at it, let's put sex, 
childbirths and deaths all on daytime TV, and give them all the U rating 
for *Universal*, because they're all a natural part of the circle of life.

Libertines in a nutshell.
comments.author: haitianxu

comments.text:
+haitianxu Just give up, please. This is the most ridiculous argument I've 
ever heard. You're a prude inventing your own misery.
comments.author: Mean Mr Mustard

comments.text:
+Mr Mustard Wow, is that your "come back"? That was even more pathetic than 
your so-called "argument". So much for defending your point! 

Of course you'd think a letter of complaint is pointless - someone like you 
who's so quick to resort to name-calling after losing an argument; who 
lacks common decency to the point that he wouldn't mind seeing peeping and 
pooping on daytime syndicated programs *by his own logic*. 

But here's a reality check: there are very detailed and strict daytime TV 
censorship laws in place because thankfully, the media world isn't run by 
name-calling libertines like yourself who are obtuse enough to actually 
think "anything goes" as long as it's "a natural part of life". Ellen had a 
slip-up, and she'll correct it. If you think this means you'll be seeing 
transferring of all forms of bodily fluids on daytime television in the 
near future, prepare to be satisfy your perversions elsewhere, or be sorely 
disappointed.
comments.author: haitianxu

comments.text:
+haitianxu Fine, if that's how you feel why not write a pointless complaint 
letter to Ellen's show and make no difference whatsoever to the world. 
Easily offended idiots like you need to lighten up.
comments.author: Mean Mr Mustard

comments.text:
+Mr Mustard Read much, before you respond? I already addressed your 
laughable "argument", so thoroughly in fact, that the person hasn't offered 
a come back in 10 days. But I guess ignorance is your middle name, so here 
it is again: 

By your logic, peeing and pooping are even more natural than breastfeeding 
- if breastfeeding is natural and part of being a mother, then peeing and 
pooping are natural and a part of being *human*. So, would you want to see 
people showing pictures of peeing and pooping on daytime network 
television? Exactly. People should not talk about peeing and pooping and 
breastfeeding on daytime television because they're gross and private, 
personal affairs. Have some common decency.
comments.author: haitianxu

comments.text:
+haitianxu No, breastfeeding is natural and part of being a mother. Stop 
being so oversensitive.
comments.author: Mean Mr Mustard

comments.text: +Mr Mustard It's called common decency, something you distinctly lack.
comments.author: haitianxu

comments.text: What a prude.
comments.author: Mean Mr Mustard

natural than breastfeeding, as 100% of the population pees multiple times a 
day. That said, would you want to see people peeing on daytime network 
television? Exactly. People should not talk about peeing and pooping and 
breastfeeding on daytime television because they're gross. Ew.

- EXACTLY.
- YOU KNOW?
"OH, YOU'RE BUSY TODAY?
"LET ME BREASTFEED YOUR CHILD,

'CAUSE I NEED TO LOSE
TEN POUNDS."
- I COULD HAVE BEEN THAT.

I COULD HAVE BEEN THE WET NURSE
IN MEDIEVAL TIMES.

I COULD HAVE FED THE VILLAGE
WHILE THEY ALL WENT TO WORK.

title: Emily Blunt on Her New Baby
